questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presented with a small, pearly nodule measuring 0.3 cm on the left nasolabial fold, with occasional bleeding. The lesion was excised, and histopathological examination was performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 0.3 cm nodule on the left nasolabial fold is most likely to represent a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), especially given the location on the nasolabial fold, which is a common site for BCC.

Melanoma (Option B) is a malignant tumor from melanocytes, typically appearing as a dark, irregular lesion-not a small, pearly nodule like in this case.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option C) presents as a scaly or ulcerated nodule and has a higher risk of metastasis, unlike the slow-growing, pearly BCC.

Nevus (Option D) is a benign, well-circumscribed pigmented lesion, usually flat or slightly raised, and not pearly or firm like basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old ICU patient with sepsis is receiving Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN). Which of the following metabolic complications is most likely to occur in this clinical setting?
questions.solution:
A common complication of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN), especially in critically ill patients with sepsis, is hyperglycemia, driven by the high glucose content of TPN and insulin resistance associated with sepsis.

  • It is indicated in patients who are unable to meet their nutritional requirements via absorption of nutrients from their intestinal tract.
  • The most common cause is in patients with short bowel syndrome (massive intestinal resection or a significant reduction in functional small bowel).

Hyperlipidemia (Option A): TPN may cause elevated lipid levels if lipids are given in excess, but this is less common than hyperglycemia in acutely ill septic patients.

Hyperglyceridemia (Option C): TPN can raise triglyceride levels, but this is typically less frequent and less critical than hyperglycemia during acute sepsis management.

Hypoglycemia (Option D): Can occur if TPN is abruptly stopped or due to insulin overdose, but in septic patients, hyperglycemia is far more common due to stress response and insulin resistance.

Learning Objective:

TPN Formulations:

choices.text: Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics
Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis
Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement
Perform an endoscopy to look for varices

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with severe vomiting of blood. Ultrasound reveals a distended portal vein and a hyperechoic liver. He has been started on pantoprazole. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic with severe hematemesis, distended portal vein, and hypoechoic liver suggests Upper GI (gastrointestinal) Bleeding, requiring immediate stabilisation with intravenous fluids with electrolyte replacement.

Management:

  • PPI/Tranexamic acid/Octreotide administration.
  • IV fluids and electrolyte replacement to stabilise the patient. (Option C)
  • Endoscopic variceal ligation is performed, followed by endoscopic sclerotherapy.(Option D ruled out)

Following is the algorithm used for management:

Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option A): Antibiotics are initiated only after the bleeding has been controlled.

Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis (Option B): Liver biopsy is not necessary in the initial management of upper GI bleed.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of recurrent diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and foul-smelling stools. Colonoscopy reveals characteristic mucosal changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of recurrent diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and foul-smelling stools, along with colonoscopy revealing raised, yellowish-white plaques or pseudomembranes on the mucosal surface, indicates Pseudomembranous Colitis.

FAP (Option B): An inherited condition with numerous colonic polyps, typically without recurrent diarrhea or foul-smelling stools. Colonoscopy shows multiple polyps, not pseudomembranes.

Ulcerative colitis (Option C): Causes abdominal pain and diarrhea, but colonoscopy reveals continuous mucosal ulceration, not pseudomembranes.

Acute gastritis (Option D): Affects the stomach, presenting with upper abdominal pain and nausea. It doesn't cause diarrhea, and colonoscopy isn't used for diagnosis.

questions.text: On postoperative day 3, how does a skin graft primarily receive its nutrition?
questions.solution:
On day 3 post-grafting, the graft depends primarily on Imbibition for its nutrition.

  • It is the process by which the graft absorbs nutrients and oxygen directly from the surrounding tissue through diffusion.
  • Occurs within the first 72 hours post-transplantation.

Skin graft Take:

The process of skin graft healing is called "Skin graft Take." The phases ofgraft takeinvolve a series of 3 steps critical for the successful integration of a graft into the recipient site. These phases are:

  • Serum Imbibition (Plasmatic Circulation): In the first 48 hours, the graft is sustained by plasma exudate from the capillaries in the host bed. (Option A)
  • Inosculation, where graft and host vessels form direct connections (complete in 4-5 days). (Option B ruled out)
  • Neovascularization, where new blood vessels grow from the recipient site into the graft. It starts after imbibition and inosculation, around 7 to 14 days post-grafting. (Option C ruled out)

Organisation: This phase begins immediately after grafting, with a fibrin layer forming at the graft-bed interface to stabilise the graft. By day 7, this layer is replaced by fibroblasts, and by days 10 to 14, the graft is typically well-adhered to the underlying bed.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551561/

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents with new-onset confusion. He is on antihypertensives and aspirin after a recent myocardial infarction. He reports a minor fall from a chair about three weeks ago. Neurological examination is unremarkable. Based on the imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario of confusion, recent MI, antihypertensive and aspirin use, a minor fall, and a crescent-shaped, hyperdense, or isodense lesion on CT points to a Subdural Hematoma (SDH), typically caused by bridging vein rupture, often following trauma or in elderly individuals.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Option C): Shows diffuse hyperdensity in the subarachnoid spaces on CT, often around sulci and ventricles, usually caused by ruptured aneurysms or AV malformations.

Contusion (Option D): Appears as localized mixed-density hemorrhages within brain tissue with surrounding edema on CT, typically focal rather than diffuse or crescent-shaped.

questions.text: A patient reports a longstanding umbilical swelling that was initially painless and reducible but has recently become painful and irreducible. What is the best management approach?
questions.solution:
The patient’s irreducible umbilical hernia with pain and unhealthy skin suggests possible strangulation or incarceration, requiring surgical intervention with umbilical excision.

Indications for umbilical hernia repair in adults:

  • Incarceration or strangulation: Requires immediate repair due to the risk of bowel necrosis.(Option A)
  • Symptomatic hernias: Indicated when the hernia causes pain or discomfort.
  • Defects larger than 2 cm: Larger defects are more prone to complications.
  • Thinning of overlying skin: Increased risk of complications, such as skin breakdown or incarceration.

Conservative management with antibiotics (Option B): Antibiotics alone don’t resolve an irreducible hernia and are inadequate if strangulation or incarceration is present.

Mesh hernioplasty (Option C): Suitable for stable, reducible hernias but contraindicated in strangulated cases where urgent surgical excision is needed.

Incision and drainage (Option D): Used for abscesses, not for irreducible hernias with possible strangulation, which require surgical repair.

Learning Objectives:

Complications of Surgery:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Bleeding/Hematoma: From subcutaneous or inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Urinary Retention: May require catheterisation.
    • Femoral Nerve Blockade
  • Early Postoperative Issues (within the first week):
    • Pain, Bruising, Swelling:
    • Seroma Formation: Often resolves spontaneously; may need aspiration.
    • Wound Infection: Less frequent;routine antibiotics not recommended.
    • Testicular Infarction:Damage to the testicular artery during dissection or repair.
  • Long-term Concerns:
    • Chronic Pain:
      • Nerve Injury: Damage to nerves such as the ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric nerves during surgery.
      • Nerve Irritation: Chronic irritation bysuture material or mesh.
      • Psychological Factors
    • Hernia Recurrence: Inadequate repair or weakness in the abdominal wall;mesh-related issues may also contribute.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging, irregular breast lump measuring 5 x 6 cm. Histopathology reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario describes a 5 x 6 cm irregular mass, and histopathological examination reveals whorled stroma and leaf-like structures, leading to a diagnosis of Phyllodes Tumor (also referred to as Phylloid Tumor or Cystosarcoma Phyllodes).

Fibroadenoma (Option B): A benign, well-circumscribed, mobile mass common in younger women, lacking the stromal overgrowth and irregularity seen in phyllodes tumors.

Mastitis (Option C): Breast infection with pain, redness, and swelling-not a discrete mass; histology shows inflammation, not tumor features.

Grade 2 breast tumour (Option D), such as invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC), exhibits moderate cellular abnormalities, increased mitotic activity, and disorganised growth, replacing normal breast tissue with irregular nests of cancerous cells. In contrast to phylloid tumours, IDC does not have a characteristic leaf-like pattern or well-formed stroma.

choices.text: Endoscopic dilation of the bladder neck

questions.text: A 3-month-old male infant is brought to the hospital with difficulty urinating, similar to an episode that occurred two weeks earlier. Catheterization was performed easily. Based on the radiographic findings, what is the best management approach?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a 3-month-old male child with difficulty passing urine, along with a similar episode 15 days ago and successful catheterisation, along with the radiograph, suggests Posterior Urethral Valves (PUV), which are managed by endoscopic ablation for valve destruction.

  • They are membranous folds that obstruct the lumen of the posterior urethra.
  • Prevalence:About 1 in 4000 live-born boys are affected (girls are not affected).
  • Clinical features:
    • Identified antenatally (bilateral hydronephrosis, a dilated bladder and a dilated posterior urethra)
      • On imaging: It appears like a keyhole.
      • Severe cases: Oligohydramnios and lung hypoplasia
    • Postnatal presentations
      • Urinary tract infections
      • Bladder distension
      • Voiding dysfunction.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Voiding Cystourethrogram (VCUG): Shows a dilated posterior urethra with a thick-walled bladder.
    • Ultrasonography: Hydronephrosis and a thickened bladder.
    • Renal function can be assessed with routine blood tests and glomerular filtration rate or a DMSA scan.
  • Management:
    • The valves are ablated or resected (Option B)
      • Endoscopic Ablation: Involves using a cystoscope to remove or ablate the obstructive valve tissue, thereby relieving the obstruction and improving urine flow.
    • Close follow-up is needed (risk for bladder dysfunction and renal failure).

Partial resection of verumontanum (Option A): Used for prostatic obstruction, not for posterior urethral valves (PUV).

Endoscopic dilation of bladder neck (Option C): Treats bladder neck obstruction, not PUV, which affects the posterior urethra.

Indwelling catheter (Option D): Provides temporary relief but doesn’t address the underlying PUV; definitive treatment requires valve ablation.

questions.text: At what is the earliest age a unilateral cleft lip in a newborn can typically be surgically repaired?
questions.solution:
The earliest age at which a unilateral cleft lip in a newborn can be corrected is 5-6 months.

Timing of Repair:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a painless thyroid nodule. Fine needle aspiration biopsy reveals the following. Genetic testing identifies a common mutation associated with this tumor. Which mutation is most likely present?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painless thyroid nodule with the given histological image shows papillary projections and optically clear nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei), indicating Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC), which is associated with the BRAF mutation.

Types of thyroid carcinomas:

questions.text: A man arrives at the emergency department following a road traffic accident, complaining of chest pain and difficulty breathing. Imaging reveals the following. What type of breathing pattern is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the case of RTA with chest pain and shortness of breath, accompanied by an X-ray showing more than three consecutive rib fractures, a Flail Chest is diagnosed, leading to the observation of paradoxical breathing.

  • Occurs when three or more consecutive ribs are fractured in at least two places, creating a flail segment that moves independently.
  • It exhibits paradoxical chest movement (inwards during inhalation & outwards during exhalation)
  • Features:
    • Hypoventilation: Reduced lung ventilation leads to low oxygen and high CO2 levels.
    • Mediastinal Flutter: Abnormal mediastinal movement risks sudden cardiac arrest.
    • Pendular Air Movement: Inefficient air exchange between lungs.
  • Complications:
    • Hemothorax: Blood in the chest cavity.
    • Pneumothorax: Air in the chest cavity.
  • Treatment:
    • Ventilation Support:
      • Oxygen supplementation and Analgesics- Initial management
      • IPPV is the preferred TOC.
      • Tracheostomy if support exceeds 10 days.
    • Injury Management:
      • Intercostal Tube Drainage: Removes air/fluids from the pleural space.
      • Rib Fixation: Stabilises the chest wall.
    • Supportive Care:
      • Blood Transfusions: For blood loss.
      • IV Fluids: For hydration.
      • Antibiotics: To prevent infection.
      • Medications: Bronchodilators and steroids.
    • Thoracotomy:
      • Considered in severe cases

Cheyne-Stokes (Option A): Cycles of deep breaths and apnea seen in heart failure or brain injury, not involving paradoxical chest movement.

Biot (Option B): Irregular shallow breaths with apnea, linked to brain damage, without paradoxical chest motion.

Kussmaul (Option C): Deep, rapid breathing due to metabolic acidosis, not associated with paradoxical chest movement seen in flail chest.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent headaches, episodes of high blood pressure, and rapid heartbeat. Urine analysis reveals elevated vanillylmandelic acid levels, and a CT scan shows a retroperitoneal mass near the right kidney. Which of the following syndromes is least likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution: The given scenario, featuring a headache, recurrent high blood pressure, tachycardia, elevated levels of vanillylmandelic acid in the urine, and a CT scan revealing a retroperitoneal tumour in the right lumbar region, is diagnosed as Pheochromocytoma, which is associated with NF1, but not NF2.

choices.text: Urethral repair with graft from buccal mucosa

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives with sudden inability to urinate and has undergone suprapubic catheterization for bladder drainage. Imaging with a retrograde urethrogram reveals the following. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario of acute urinary retention, which is relieved through a suprapubic catheter, a retrograde urethrogram reveals a Urethral Stricture. The management involves urethral repair using a buccal mucosa graft (urethroplasty).


Metallic catheter placement (Option B) is not a definitive treatment. Metallic catheters are used in some cases for long-term drainage, but they do not address the underlying stricture.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum is indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step
A bilateral orchidectomy must be done

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes to the emergency department with sudden severe pain in the perineal region. Examination reveals foul-smelling discharge and necrotic tissue involving the genital area, as shown in the image. Which of the following statements about this condition is correct?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation suggests Fournier's gangrene, a severe soft tissue infection involving the perineum. This condition is typically caused by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection.
  • The most common aerobic microorganisms include Escherichia coli, Proteus, Staphylococcus, Klebsiella, and Streptococcus.
  • The predominant anaerobic microorganisms are Bacteroides, Clostridium, and Peptostreptococcus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man reports persistent pain and numbness on the outer aspect of his right thigh following a recent bilateral laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. Which nerve is most likely compressed or injured, causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
• The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is commonly implicated in thigh pain following laparoscopic hernia repair. It can become entrapped during the surgical procedure, leading to meralgia paresthetica, a condition characterised by pain, tingling, or numbness along the outer thigh.
  • The most common nerve injured in:
    • Open repair: Ilio-inguinal (Option A) > Iliohypogastric (Option B) > Genital branch of GFN.
    • Laparoscopy: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genito-femoral nerve(GFN).
  • Landmarks in Laparoscopic Surgery:
    • Triangle of Doom: Injury to Iliac vessels
    • Triangle of Pain: Injury to Nerves causing postoperative pain

Complications of Surgery:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Bleeding/Hematoma: From subcutaneous or inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Urinary Retention: May require catheterisation.
    • Femoral Nerve Blockade (Option C)
  • Early Postoperative Issues (within the first week):
    • Pain, Bruising, Swelling:
    • Seroma Formation: Often resolves spontaneously; may need aspiration.
    • Wound Infection: Less frequent; routine antibiotics not recommended.
    • Testicular Infarction: Damage to the testicular artery during dissection or repair.
  • Long-term Concerns:
    • Chronic Pain:
      • Nerve Injury: Damage to nerves such as the ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric nerves during surgery.
      • Nerve Irritation: Chronic irritation by suture material or mesh.
      • Psychological Factors
    • Hernia Recurrence: Inadequate repair or weakness in the abdominal wall; mesh-related issues may also contribute.

questions.text: What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of a patient who was admitted to the emergency room after being involved in a road traffic accident and, on examination, opens his eyes in response to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs in response to a painful stimulus?
questions.solution:
• Eye-opening (E): The patient opens their eyes in response to a painful stimulus, which corresponds to E2 (eye-opening to pain).
  • Verbal response (V): The patient speaks inappropriately, corresponding to V3 (inappropriate words).
  • Motor response (M): The patient withdraws their limbs in response to a painful stimulus, which corresponds to M4 (withdraws to pain).

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):



The GCS-P score is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score: GCS-P = GCS - PRS.


  • GCS-P score can range from 1 to 15
  • GCS-P score values between one and 8 denote a severe injury

Reference:

https://www.glasgowcomascale.org/what-is-gcs-p/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513298/

questions.text: A patient presents with features of chronic pancreatitis, including recurrent attacks, and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
In chronic pancreatitis with dilated pancreatic ducts and intraductal stones, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is commonly performed to relieve obstruction and drain the pancreatic duct. This procedure is effective in managing pain and improving pancreatic function.

Treatment of Chronic Pancreatitis:

Medical Management: Most patients with chronic pancreatitis can be managed with medical measures. There is no single therapeutic agent proven to relieve all symptoms. The primary goals are to manage pain, prevent complications, and address nutritional issues. Medical approaches include:

  • Treating the Addiction
  • Pain relief
  • Nutritional Support and Pharmacological Measures:
    • Diet: Low in fat, high in protein and carbohydrates.
    • Pancreatic Enzyme Supplementation with meals to aid digestion.
    • Micronutrient Therapy: Correct malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) and vitamin B12, and provide supplements like methionine, vitamins C and E, and selenium, which may reduce pain and slow disease progression.
    • Reducing gastric secretions may help some patients.
    • Diabetes Management may be required if pancreatic damage leads to endocrine dysfunction.

Surgical interventions:


Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Option A) is a major surgery primarily for pancreatic head tumors and is not the first-line treatment for chronic pancreatitis with intraductal stones.

ERCP and sphincterotomy (Option C) can be effective for dominant strictures or obstructions but are less suitable when there is significant ductal dilation with large stones.

Coring of the pancreatic head (Frey’s procedure) (Option D) removes diseased tissue in chronic pancreatitis but is not the preferred option for cases with markedly dilated ducts and intraductal calculi.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a long history of diabetes presents with a painless ulcer on the sole of his right foot. He reports numbness and tingling in both feet for several years. Examination revealed the following image. There is diminished sensation to pain and temperature in the affected foot. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The painless nature of the ulcer, its location on the sole, and the presence of sensory loss due to diabetic neuropathy strongly indicate a trophic (neuropathic) ulcer.

Trophic ulcers, also called neuropathic ulcers, occur due to a loss of sensation and an impaired ability to protect the skin, often resulting from conditions like peripheral neuropathy or poor circulation. These ulcers usually have well-defined borders and a pale or pink wound bed, commonly located in weight-bearing areas where pressure or friction is frequent.

Type of Ulcer:


Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3036466/

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a history of untreated varicose veins in her lower leg presents with itching, redness, and scaling of the skin around the ankle. On examination, there is visible eczema and mild pigmentation changes over the affected area, along with prominent varicose veins.According to the CEAP classification, what is the clinical stage of her chronic venous disease?
questions.solution:
According to the CEAP (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) classification system for chronic venous disease, C4a refers to skin changes such as eczema or pigmentation in the presence of varicose veins.


Pigmentation/Eczema

LDS

Atrophic blanche

Corona phlebectatica

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557410/

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents with a swelling in the midline of his neck that shifts when he swallows or sticks out his tongue. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A thyroglossal cyst is a midline neck swelling that typically moves with swallowing or protrusion of the tongue.

It results from incomplete closure of the thyroglossal duct, which is an embryological remnant. The cyst often lies in close proximity to the hyoid bone and can be felt to shift with movement of the tongue or swallowing.

Thyroglossal Cyst:

  • It is a congenital neck mass resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct, an embryological structure. It can also be present in adulthood.
  • The cyst represents a remnant of this duct and can be found anywhere along the midline from the base of the tongue to the thyroid isthmus.
  • It presents as midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue.
  • Most Common Site: Subhyoid (can also be seen on the floor of the mouth, Suprahyoid, near thyroid cartilage and foramen caecum)

Treatment:

  • Sistrunk Procedure: Complete surgical excision of the cyst and its tract up to the base of the tongue and a portion of the hyoid bone to prevent recurrence.
  • Incision and drainage are never done as they lead to the formation of a Thyroglossal fistula. (It also forms if an inflamed cyst ruptures.)-Always Acquired.

Brachial cyst (Option A): A brachial cyst, or branchial cleft cyst, generally appears as a lump along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, not in the midline of the neck.

Plunging ranula (Option C) is a mucous cyst found in the floor of the mouth, typically located laterally rather than in the midline, and it usually doesn't shift with swallowing or tongue protrusion.

Dermoid cyst (Option D), a type of teratoma, is often present at birth and can appear in the midline of the neck. However, these cysts typically do not move with swallowing or tongue protrusion.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with confusion, rapid breathing, and low blood pressure. She has a history of urinary tract infection and now shows signs of sepsis. To quickly assess her risk of poor outcomes, the physician decides to calculate the qSOFA score. Which of the following parameters are included in the qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
The qSOFA score includes three components: Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) less than 100 mmHg, Respiratory Rate (RR) greater than or equal to 22 breaths per minute, and a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score. These components help in the assessment of organ failure and sepsis prognosis.

Sepsis & q SOFA:

Sepsis is now defined as an increase of 2 or more points in the Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score from baseline. However, calculating the full SOFA score can be complex and requires lab results, so a simpler tool, the quick SOFA (qSOFA) score, was introduced for bedside use.

  • qSOFA Criteria: qSOFA involves evaluating three key signs:
    • Respiratory rate ≥ 22 breaths per minute
    • Altered mental status (GCS score)
    • Systolic blood pressure ≤ 100 mmHg (hypotension)
  • If a patient meets at least 2 of the 3 qSOFA criteria and is at risk for sepsis (e.g., has an infection), further evaluation should be conducted to identify the source of infection and initiate appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man arrives at the emergency department after a minor fall while hiking. He complains of mild pain and swelling in his left wrist but is able to walk and move without difficulty. His vital signs are stable, and he has no other injuries.According to triage classification, into which category does this patient fall?
questions.solution:
In triage, patients are categorised based on the urgency of their medical needs, and the green category is for ambulatory patients, meaning those who are able to walk and have non-life-threatening injuries.


Moderate priority (Option B) can be classified as yellow in triage. These patients have conditions that are serious but not immediately life-threatening. They may require medical attention, but they can still wait for a period without their condition deteriorating rapidly.

High priority (Option C) is generally categorised as red in triage, indicating immediate care is required. These patients have life-threatening injuries or conditions and need immediate medical intervention.

Dead patients (Option D) are not part of the triage process, as they are not classified for further care. Triage prioritises patients based on the severity of their condition to allocate resources effectively, focusing on those who can be saved or treated.

questions.text: A male patient presents with impotence and absent femoral pulse. The pain in the gluteal region is observed. At which level has the pathology occurred?
questions.solution:
• Aortoiliac bifurcation pathology is the most likely cause of the combination of symptoms described.
  • Leriche's syndrome refers to a specific form of aortoiliac occlusion that results from the blockage or narrowing of the aortoiliac bifurcation, leading to reduced blood flow to the lower limbs and pelvic organs.
  • Clinical features of this syndrome include:
    • Impotence
    • Claudication
    • Absent femoral pulses
    • Gluteal pain

Bilateral internal iliac arteries (Option B) can lead to impotence and pain in the gluteal region, but they do not cause the absence of a femoral pulse.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who is a chronic alcoholic presents with oral ulcers and a burning sensation. A picture of the oral cavity is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Leukoplakia is a precancerous lesion that typically presents as white patches or plaques on the mucosal surfaces, often seen in the mouth, tongue, and gums.


Erythroplakia (Option B) appears as a bright red, velvety patch with a high risk of malignant transformation but usually does not cause burning like leukoplakia.

Submucosal fibrosis (Option C) causes progressive mucosal fibrosis leading to trismus and tongue stiffness, without primarily causing oral ulcers.

Malakoplakia (Option D) is a rare inflammatory condition with soft yellow plaques, mostly affecting immunocompromised patients and typically involving the genitourinary tract, not the oral cavity.

questions.text: Please determine the extent of burn injuries in a preschool-aged child portrayed in the attached image.
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is 25-30%, based on the Rule of Nines estimation method.
  • Since the patient in the scenario is a child,
  • Burnt area %: Back fully burn 18% + some upper and lower chest 9% approx, so in total approx 25 to 30%
  • According to the Wallace rule of 9, this is how the area burned is calculated:

questions.text: A young male patient with a history of a motor vehicle accident cannot pass urine. Blood is seen at the meatus. What is the most likely site of urethral injury?
questions.solution:
• The most likely site of urethral injury in a young male with the inability to urinate, blood at the meatus, and a history of motor vehicle accidents is the membranous urethra.
  • In the picture, a retrograde urethrogram is shown to assess for extravasation, and the leak is noted proximal to the bulbar urethra, indicating injury to the membranous urethra

Bulbar urethra (Option A) lies in the penile shaft and is more flexible; it's commonly injured in straddle injuries or perineal blows, not typically in motor vehicle accidents.

Spongy urethra (Option B), also called the penile urethra, runs along the penis shaft and is usually injured in penile trauma, while motor vehicle accidents tend to cause pelvic fractures affecting the membranous urethra.

Penile urethra (Option D) refers to the urethra along the penile shaft, prone to injury from direct trauma, but motor vehicle accidents more commonly damage the membranous urethra due to pelvic fractures.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with intermittent right-sided flank pain that worsens after fluid intake. He denies fever or urinary symptoms. Physical examination is unremarkable. A delayed intravenous urogram done revealed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic presentation of intermittent flank pain exacerbated by diuresis, along with delayed contrast drainage on IVU, strongly suggests PUJ obstruction.

  • In a delayed intravenous urogram (IVU), the delayed contrast uptake seen in the right kidney suggests an obstruction at the pelvic ureteric junction (PUJ)
  • Pelviureteric Junction (PUJ) obstruction is a condition where the flow of urine from the renal pelvis into the ureter is impeded due to a narrowing or blockage at the junction between the renal pelvis and the ureter.

Putty kidney (Option B) is a sequela of genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB) characterised by "extensive dystrophic calcification involving all or most of the kidney, seen as calcified non-functioning renal tissue." It is the end stage of renal tuberculosis, which causes the kidney to malfunction.

Staghorn calculus (Option C) is a large kidney stone that fills the renal pelvis and branches out into the calyces, forming a shape resembling a stag's antlers. It is also known as triple phosphate stone (MgNH4Po4), which is caused by recurrent UTI and is associated with urea-splitting organisms.

Cystic kidney (Option D) is a condition in which the kidneys contain numerous fluid-filled sacs or cysts. This can cause enlargement of the kidneys and impair their function, but it does not cause obstruction or delay of contrast dye uptake, as seen in the image provided.

choices.text: Osteoma of the floor of the mouth

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient complained of pain in one side of the neck. She is afraid of eating food as it worsens the pain. Ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands is done and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's postprandial neck pain and ultrasound showing a hyperechoic lesion in the salivary gland are characteristic of sialolithiasis, most commonly affecting the submandibular gland.

  • Sialolithiasis refers to the formation of salivary stones (sialoliths) in the salivary glands, which commonly occur in the submandibular gland.
  • Ultrasound imaging is one of the most common diagnostic tools for identifying sialoliths, as it can show hyperechoic areas indicative of salivary stones and their location in the gland.

Foreign body (Option B):Usually follows trauma or ingestion; pain is not typically meal-related, and ultrasound would show a distinct object, not a salivary stone.

Osteoma of the floor of the mouth (Option C):A benign bony growth not associated with salivary pain or postprandial symptoms; not well-visualised on ultrasound.

Cervical lymphadenopathy (Option D):Presents as generalised neck swelling due to infection or malignancy; not linked to eating or gland-specific tenderness like sialolithiasis.

questions.text: A patient was found to have a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach, which involves the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for a patient with a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach involving the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver is Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy.

Treatment of Stomach Cancer

  • Surgical Treatment:
    • Surgical resection is the only curative treatment for gastric cancer.
    • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy:
      • Most surgical candidates receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy to improve survival.
      • The FLOT4 trial found that the FLOT (fluorouracil, leucovorin, oxaliplatin, docetaxel) regimen offers a significant survival advantage over the ECF (epirubicin, cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil) regimen (median overall survival: 50 months vs 35 months).

Types of Gastric Resection

  • Total Gastrectomy:
    • Involves the removal of the stomach, spleen, and pancreas.
    • Includes D2 lymphadenectomy.
    • Preferred for resectable gastric cancer.
  • Subtotal Gastrectomy:
    • It may be performed if the tumour is located in the distal stomach.
    • Involves Roux-en-Y reconstruction.
  • Palliative Surgery:
    • Considered for symptom alleviation in inoperable or metastatic gastric cancer.

Non-Surgical Treatment

  • Palliative Chemotherapy or Radiotherapy: Offered to patients with advanced gastric cancer.

Radical gastrectomy (Option B) would be considered if there was no metastasis, but metastasis to the liver and involvement of the pancreas suggests an advanced stage, making this option less feasible.

Whipple's procedure (Option C) is used for pancreatic cancer; this procedure is not appropriate here due to gastric cancer with liver metastasis.

Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy (Option D) would be considered for resectable localised tumours, but with liver metastasis, it's not an ideal option for curative intent.

questions.text: A 60-year-old smoker presents with a chronic cough and unintended weight loss. Chest CT reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule measuring 2.5 cm in the right upper lobe, with no evidence of lymphadenopathy or distant metastasis. Based on the TNM staging system, what is the T stage of this lung tumour?
questions.solution: Given that the tumour size is 2.5 cm, it falls under T1c (as it is > 2 cm but ≤ 3 cm).

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on superior and inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
Lower abdominal fat-based inferior epigastric vessels

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the flap given in the image?
questions.solution:
• The flap given is DIEP (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator Flap), which involves harvesting tissue from the lower abdomen without taking the muscle.
  • The flap relies on the deep inferior epigastric artery for blood supply, making it a muscle-sparing option for breast reconstruction or other soft tissue reconstructions.
  • It is the best flap for breast reconstruction as there is no risk of hernia and muscle weakness.

Pedicled TRAM based on the superior epigastric artery (Option A): A pedicled TRAM flap involves using the skin, muscle, fat and blood vessels, but the image does not depict a Pedicled TRAM flap; the image actually shows a DIEP flap.

Lower abdominal fat-based inferior epigastric vessels (Option D) The image does not depict lower abdominal fat based on inferior epigastric vessels; the image actually shows a DIEP flap.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids and regurgitation of undigested food. High-resolution manometry reveals pan-esophageal pressurisation in ≥ 20% of swallows with incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation and failed peristalsis. According to the Chicago Classification, what type of achalasia is most likely?
questions.solution:
Type II achalasia is characterised by pan-esophageal pressurisation with failed peristalsis and elevated IRP, which best fits the manometry findings in this patient.


IRP: Integrated Relaxation Pressure

DCI: Distal Contractile Integral

DL: Distal Latency

Type IV (Option C) is not part of the classification mentioned above.

questions.text:
Which of the following are risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma?
1.Hepatitis B
2.PSC
3.Caroli's disease
4.Opisthorchis viverrini
questions.solution: NIH Link.

choices.text: MIBI followed by focussed parathyroidectomy to be done
Normal DEXA scan rules out the need for surgery
Only observation, no need for surgery
Creatinine clearance > 80 ml/min mandates the surgery

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a serum calcium level of 12.8 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5-10.25 mg/dL) along with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. Ultrasound imaging reveals a 1.5 x 1.5 cm mass in the right lower lobe of the thyroid gland. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
• MIBI scan followed by focused parathyroidectomy is the recommended course of action for this patient.
  • This scenario suggests primary hyperparathyroidism, likely due to a parathyroid adenoma, given the elevated calcium and PTH levels, along with the thyroid mass that could be related to a parathyroid lesion.
  • Sestamibi scan is a type of nuclear medicine-based study that is most accurate for parathyroid lesion localisation.
  • Indications of parathyroidectomy include: (Option C ruled out)
    • Severe symptoms
    • Young age
    • Markedly reduced bone density
    • Serum calcium more than 11mg%
    • Urinary calculi
    • Neuromuscular symptoms
    • Urinary calcium more than 400mg/24 hour

Normal DEXA scan rules out the need for surgery (Option B) is not true because even if bone density is normal, elevated calcium and PTH levels indicate that the parathyroid adenoma should be addressed surgically.

Creatinine clearance > 80 ml/min mandates the surgery (Option D): Surgical intervention is primarily indicated based on the diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism and the presence of complications or symptoms, not just creatinine clearance.

Learning Objective:

Indications of surgery in an asymptomatic case are:

  • Serum calcium 25 mmol/L (1.0 mg/dL) above the upper limit of normal
  • Bone mineral density (BMD) by DEXA; T score -2.5 at lumbar spine, total hip, femoral neck, or distal one-third of radius
  • Vertebral fracture
  • Creatinine clearance <60 mL/min
  • 24-hour urinary calcium >10 mmol/dL (>400 mg/day) or increased risk of stone formation by risk analysis
  • Age <50 years
  • When medical therapy is not possible

choices.text: Start PRBC 1st and store platelet at room temperature
Start platelet and store PRBC at room temperature
Transfuse PRBC and store platelet at 2-6 degrees

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining multiple stab wounds to the abdomen. He is hypotensive, tachycardic, and shows signs of hemorrhagic shock. There is only one IV access established, and the blood bank has issued 2 units of PRBC and 1 unit of platelets. What is the most appropriate immediate step?
questions.solution:
In hemorrhagic shock, restoring circulating volume and oxygen-carrying capacity takes priority, making PRBC transfusion the immediate need. Platelets can safely be kept at room temperature for a short time without loss of function and should be administered once another line is available.

Start platelet and store PRBC at room temperature (Option B) In a situation of massive blood loss, addressing acute anemia by transfusing PRBCs takes precedence over platelet transfusion.

Only transfuse PRBC (Option C) While PRBC transfusion is necessary for addressing the acute anemia, platelet transfusion should also be considered since the patient received 4 platelets from the blood bank. Platelets are vital for promoting clotting and preventing bleeding complications, particularly in patients with significant blood loss.

Transfuse PRBC and store platelet at 2-6 degrees (Option D) Storing platelets at 2-6 degrees Celsius is the recommended temperature for long-term storage, but it is not necessary when there is limited IV access and a need for immediate transfusion.

questions.text: During a laparoscopic procedure, the resident discusses port placement strategy with an intern. He explains that the angle between the two working ports should be optimized to allow smooth hand movements and prevent external clashing of instruments. What is this angle known as?
questions.solution:
• The manipulation angle is the angle between the two working ports in laparoscopic surgery. The ideal angle is approximately 60° to enable optimal triangulation, ergonomic movement, and effective instrument control.

Crossing angle (Option C) is not a term specifically used to describe the angle between the camera port and the working port.

Reference: NIH Link,

Article Link,

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Learning Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male had surgery for an ileal perforation. Due to significant contamination, only the sheath was sutured, leaving the wound open. Daily wound irrigation was carried out, and the wound was closed on postoperative day 5. What type of wound-healing mechanism is occurring in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of wound healing mechanism described in this scenario is tertiary intention (also known as (delayed primary closure).


Quaternary intention (Option D) is not a recognised term in wound healing. The proper classification includes primary, secondary, and tertiary intention.

questions.text: A patient presents with dull, aching pain and tortuous veins in both lower limbs. Which test would be appropriate for evaluating superficial femoral vein (SFJ) competence?
questions.solution:
The Brodie-Trendelenburg test/ Trendelenburg I test is done to determine the patency of the saphenofemoral junction.

  • Procedure:
    • The patient is asked to lie in the supine position.
    • The leg is elevated, the vein is emptied by "milking," and a tourniquet is tied just below the saphenofemoral junction.
    • The patient is asked to stand up quickly.
    • The tourniquet is released.
  • Observation:
    • When there is rapid filling of blood from above, this signifies saphenofemoral incompetence.

Other tests for varicose veins:


Homan's test (Option B) is a test for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) rather than venous insufficiency. It involves dorsiflexing the foot and assessing for pain in the calf, which may suggest a clot.
